attachments.title: MN Coursera Pilot restarted now
attachments.content_excerpt:
Dear TC CoDe Managers,
We turn to you today with really good news. MN Coursera Pilot is back and ready to go live again. Be prepared please to address the submisions already made by employees interested in the pilot, but also to further promote it from your TC CoDe level. 👉 MOOCs info page (https://nokia.sharepoint.com/sites/codeformnpcc/stratcomp/moocs/SitePages/Home.aspx)

General rules
The main rule is that one pilot participant can be assigned one token only. Check the attached power point presentation for more details on how to proceed with employees pilot submissions.
The slide deck includes:

- info on how to add employees names into the system
- info on how to add a requested training into the system
- selection of email templates that you can use when contacting pilot participants

Note that employees have access to the following Coursera learning repositories:

http://nok.it/coursera_MN
This link redirects employees to Coursera offfer for MN only which includes only approved catalog: TC + strategic competencies. The training is done here by Pilot participants.

http://nok.it/coursera_all
If employees from your TC wish to find another training offering of their interest, they will be able to look trough this Coursera general catalogue and submit the one they are interested in to be approved and added into the MN catalogue by you. 👉 MOOCs info page (https://nokia.sharepoint.com/sites/codeformnpcc/stratcomp/moocs/SitePages/Home.aspx)
Important information
Bear in mind that the Coursera vouchers are available for a relatively short period, that is till the end of March 2019. Therefore, the sooner you promote the program locally, the bigger chance it will reach your target audience and be continued further into 2019. Note also that employees from Germany and France for the time being cannot join the pilot because of legal restrictions. 👉 MOOCs info page (https://nokia.sharepoint.com/sites/codeformnpcc/stratcomp/moocs/SitePages/Home.aspx)
Thank you for your attention.
Coursera Pilot Team

cc: Dziemianko, Katarzyna (Nokia - PL/Wroclaw), Cervenca-Lates, Augustin (Nokia - RO/Timisoara)

attachments.content_excerpt:
姓名：宫本红
部门：研发部
地点：青岛

• 参与的公司组织的CSR活动名称+贡献小时数：

2017年3月26日，“守护海岸线”海洋科研监测活动，贡献约5小时。

2017年5月5日，《我的未来会更好》公益活动，担任主讲老师，贡献约33小时。

2017年6月5日至8日，江西鹰潭电脑公益，担任主讲老师，贡献约104小时。

• 参与的非公司组织的其他CSR活动名称+贡献小时数

创办头马俱乐部公众号‘ALUQingdaoToastmaster'，定期发布俱乐部活动总结，演讲汇总等，累计发布上百篇文章，贡献100小时以上。

担任头马俱乐部财务官，小区比赛评委，贡献100小时以上。

• 公益感言（文字或视频均可）

快乐奉献，快乐成长。感恩公司有大爱，助我开启公益之旅。自2014年第一次参加公司组织的JA活动，担任主讲老师，先后又跟随公司的脚步，分别于2015年，2017年两次参加“电脑再生公益活动_江西站”，担任班级主题活动主讲老师，并参加《我的未来会更好》公益活动，担任主讲老师。每一次公益活动，都有幸结识来自五湖四海的志愿者，还有渴望成长的孩子们，志愿者们的多才多艺，倾情奉献，孩子们的天真烂漫，感动着我，激励着我。公益无处不在，公益从小事做起，公益从身边做起，号召家人与孩子一起参与“守护海岸线”海洋科研监测活动；号召小组同事一起为公司发起社会公益项目捐资捐助；创办公司头马俱乐部公众号‘ALUQingdaoToastmaster'，定期发布俱乐部活动总结，演讲汇总等，累计发布上百篇文章。快乐公益，快乐你我他。

• 公益活动照片和小视频

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story - 12

Katie Zhang (DMTS/Technical Leader, MN CC TAS R&D)

I joined x-Lucent in 2003 after getting Master Degree of Computer Science and Technology. Over the past 15 years, I worked on the iNXT/Excel (Intelligent Next-Gen Exchange Technology), IMS and TAS projects. In all these periods, I got in-depth technical expertise, technical skills, and architecture knowledge; to name a few of the expertise, it covers many functional areas such as service centralization and continuity, webRTC, IMS inter-working with Over-The-Top related services, video calls, instant message, presence (SIP/SDP and XMPP/Jingle inter-working), VoIP, Call processing, H248/MEGACO and lawful interception. 

As a testimonial of the contributions, I was nominated and awarded with the membership of Alcatel-Lucent Technical Academy (ALTA) in 2010 and granted DMTS in 2013.

To achieve new height in my career, I am keeping inquisitive on new technology besides completing my owned projects/function areas. In 2012, webRTC/HTML5 is new technology tied deeply with telecommunication. How to leverage this new technology and IMS project is my inquisitive question. Thanks to Qingdao innovation open source platform, several volunteers saw same interest as me in webRTC and I led this volunteer team to complete PoC of webRTC gateway

In 2016, I moved to Nokia TAS to take the ownership of NTAS SCC profile (SCCAS) with ~20 new engineers. Till now, the team takes full ownership and has stabilized its roadmap for customer delivery. As an application architect, I lead the team to keep being in-search-of-excellence. With several tough items practice, team  on-time delivers the projects, takes initiatives to enhance the serviceability, innovates to improve product quality and work efficiency, provides technical reference to NTAS other profiles and contributes building-block to the Nokia MN family. As a result, team gained high passion, high engagement and excellent team work with fruitful achievements.

**********************************************************************
If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story - 11

Sudhakar JBG (Project Manager/Maintenance, MN CC IMS R&D)

First decade: Individual growth : My career was born outside of this company but I was warmly adopted into erstwhile Siemens in 1998. Developed software in C/C++ and Java for ADMOSS, Corporate GSM and contributed as Test architect of Network Management Software. One year in US and one year in Germany provided exposure to various cultures. So in the growing days of my carrier the company provided me all nourishments of hike, onsite opportunity and promotions to become a strong individual.
Second decade: Growing with product: Being part of Siemens, experienced a wonderful marriage with Nokia. This brought a tremendous opportunity, to grow in terms of responsibility.  Witnessing the growth of IMS in Bangalore I was able to contribute as architect and project manager and was involved in various transfer activities. The responsibility of maintenance releases has given me lot of freedom to interface with all other teams within Nokia and also the end customers.

Inspiration : “Human Possibilities” In spite of coming from various background, all of us are inspired with the word of human and its possibilities…  What a tag line any company can have…  Whenever I face a setback this tag line “Human possibilities” comes in front and allows me to accept the short coming as human and immediately energizes me to find the possibilities to overcome them.
Rajeev’s clear and transparent communication and the transformation the company is going through makes me trust the leader and follow him as role model at work. In one of the all hands, he mentions that he does every work of his with same passion and energy, this charges me to embrace any role that the company offers as an opportunity. There is always a personal learning in every role for me to grow as an individual and contribute along with the team towards the common goal.
Looking Ahead : As an individual, I have gained a lot being in this company. Every day when I wear the badge, I bend my head with lot of respect for Nokia and when I take it out in the evening, I end my day with gratitude of providing me a platform to work.   It is neither the pay, power nor the position but its “the passion to transform myself and human lives”, drive me to work.

**********************************************************************
If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer

attachments.title: Your voice matters! Invitation to participate in the Change Map survey
attachments.content_excerpt:
Yesterday you have received the invitation to the Change Map survey (https://survey.changetracking.com/survey/nokia/mn-all/cycle-3) via email. The survey results will help us to continue our journey to become an architecture-driven organization.

Please complete this anonymous web-based Change Map questionnaire, it takes only 15 to 20 minutes. All individual responses are strictly confidential and reported to Mobile Networks on squad group/team, tribe and unit level anonymously.

The survey is open till September 7th, please click the following link:
- https://survey.changetracking.com/survey/nokia/mn-all/cycle-3
- Your username is your email address (firstname.lastname@nokia.com (mailto:firstname.lastname@nokia.com) or firstname.lastname@nokia-sbell.com (mailto:firstname.lastname@nokia-sbell.com))

Based on the results, we will be able to respond appropriately to issues and concerns, and develop an action plan for improvement together with you. Your input is important for the successful transformation of Mobile Networks!

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story - 10

Antoine Bescond (MN 5G RAN Lannion) 

I've started working for Alcatel in 2005, and ever since I've always been in R&D environment assuming different roles for different projects. First I was Test & Validation Engineer for EAUS (Extended Assistant User Profile) Project, then I've been working as Support & Maintenance Engineer for the 1430 uHSS (unified Home Subscriber Server). I had to assume several roles : support and maintenance, provide 24/7 'on-call' support for after-hours calls, install and deploy our product at T- Mobile on different U.S. sites. When our product became more mature I've trained installation and level 2 support teams.
 
It last for almost 2 years then I became Software Design & Development Engineer for DDM (Distributed Database Management), a framework to access distributed databases for the SDM. It was my will to be more in what I considered the heart of the product. I became a technical expert, working closely with both test and support teams. I also had to train and support of "on call" staff. My previous experiences helped me by giving me a better understanding of their expectations. It was a big project with licenses sold for hundreds of millions of subscribers around the world, the kind of project that makes you feel that quality really matters.
 
And in 2016 I needed new challenges I wanted to change to get out of my comfort zone so I've joined the SDL Project and more specifically the Service Discovery. SDL is a distributed shared data storage designed for the cloud, Service Discovery role is to provide up-to-date view of the available services.
This was really a nice experience : allowing me to discover Go language, microservices architecture for the cloud with good continuous integration, working with agile methodologies. It has also been for me the opportunity to experiment management being my squad leader deputy and acting as scrum master.
 
Recently in 2018  as part of MN quarterly reassignments and reorganizations 3000 employees  were offered the opportunity to move from their MN unit to 5G RAN – to further strengthen our 5G development-related technology, and providing the employees with the opportunity to work in high-priority areas and broaden their skills." I was one of them, I will now lead a squad for AirPhone (a simulator for 5G nodeB).

**********************************************************************
If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer!

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story - 9

Sureshbabu AG (Tribe Leader, MN CC Architecture & Specification)

24 years in NOKIA in various roles in RD and Systems Engineering/Architecture. Started as a Software Developer in RD with SIEMENS.
Worked on various Telecom systems like ATM Cross Connects/Switches, Management Systems, IMS - REGISTERs, CSCF, Policy control etc.
Along the way, led development teams as Line manager, headed RD organizations, executed Site strategies, knowledge/people ramp-ups. Presently a Tribe leader for MN CC Architecture.
Led various change projects in my tenure. Most of my years were spent on high intensity Change projects to do RD organization transformations, Knowledge transfers/ramp-ups, Product creation, Architecture transformations, pitching new ideas and architectures with our customers.
Passionate about right product and software design. Keenly interested to do the most frugal yet elegant implementation of customer requirements.

Restless about status quo, passionate about change. 
Every problem is a challenge and every challenge is an opportunity. Love to have challenges bring out the best in me.
100% involved in whatever I do, I am focused and bring the “cut the crap and come to the point” attitude to work.

Factors leading to my career progression:
I see this as a privilege to lead the Architecture responsibility of MN CC and am always making proposals to make a positive business impact to Core.
Never say die attitude/persistence in even hopeless situations.
My total involvement in what I do despite the fact that I had similar responsibilities as today, a decade ago.
Ability to make impactful presentations and solutions to the customers.

My wish on career progression for others:
Don’t build the desire to move up. Build enough competence and work up your appetite to solve the problems of today. We have too many people desiring higher positions but it is equally important to be the deserving ones than the desiring ones.

**********************************************************************
If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer!

body.parsed:
The 1st SAFe PI Planning for UDM

On Aug 1st, the first SAFe PI planning was launched in UDM Tribe after two months preparation. UDM Kicked-off SAFe Transformation from end of May and immediately identified key roles & responsibility, started SAFe training, defined the Value stream & ART & new process & tools, create prioritized single backlog etc. And everything and everyone is ready to launch PI planning after rehearsal in week 30.

Entire Qingdao UDM team and key roles from BLR joined the PI planning in Demo center. BLR team member remotely joined video conference. After a quick open speech from SPC Jef, PI planning started with business context from business owner (Prasad Manapoty) covering the current market share (No.1 in the world), competition, customer view and expectations from the Tribe. Followed by Product/Solution Vision from product manager (Nathan Liu), this cover our product vision, PI objectives and prioritized feature backlog. System Architecture (Cs, Kiran) delivered the architecture highlight and evolution roadmap. Quality team delivered new quality metrics and quality criteria in SAFe mode. 
After that, CI and NetAct adaption team shared the PI level plan and milestone for the common activities. RTE(Robert Wang) explain the whole PI planning process/tools, key check point and timeslot before lunch.

In the afternoon, 2 rounds of team break out are planned. All scrum team member sit together to break-down user story, task, ticket, risk, dependency with other ART/team and aligned the delivery schedule with iteration. All team post the detailed plan on the scrum board. Every team (PO/SM) presented their objective, iteration plan, dependency and risks.
Every team member are fully engaged to listen and discuss all team’s plan. This put all feature/task in front of everybody and gave everyone a big view of product and release. Every team member participate the planning and make the decision and commitment by themselves. This part overrun 1.5 hours as many detailed plan/risk are touched.

Management review and problem solving is held in the evening after whole day planning. Each ART share the 1st day’s output including feature backlog, plan, dependencies/risk, challenging etc. It has a long discussion regarding the release alignment, feature commitment, team capacity and customer needs.
The first day is a long day meeting and it’s amazing to have all people to align the schedule and plan all tasks together.

On the 2nd day, PI planning started with quick update for the 1st day planning and output of management review and problem solving meeting. 
Every team continued their breakdown based on the input from RTE, PM and dependent team. Team more focused on risk, dependency and problem solving in 1 and half hour. 
The final plan is worked out after lunch and every team present the final plan. RTE checked every risk/dependency from team and categorized them into “Owner, Accepted, Resolved and Mitigated). Most risks are resolved in the review meeting. Every open risk is assigned with specific owner to follow up after meeting.

Final confidence vote is given after all team’s final plan review. This is the most excited moment. Everyone is checked and all vote is >=3. Picture and video is taken to demo our confidence.  

The last but not least, planning retrospective is held. There is separate board prepared to post “what we did well” and “what we need to improve in next PI”.
Many good comments like “good preparation for the PI planning”, “well communicated on the planning”, “good facilitation”, “good teamwork” etc.
There were also some improvement needed, like “use electronic scrum boards”, “time schedule doesn’t match because of time difference” etc.
Good thing will be kept and the improvement will be made in next PI.
PI planning is successfully completed at 6:00PM, but many team discussion are still on-going in the meeting room. Everyone is are really moved to SAFe mode and learnt a lot from the first PI planning. 
It’s a new journey for everyone on the Train.
The train head out now, on-time delivery is in everyone’s hand.

All team post the detailed plan on the scrum board. Every team (PO/SM) presented their objective, iteration plan, dependency and risks.
Every team member are fully engaged to listen and discuss all team’s plan. This put all feature/task in front of everybody and gave everyone a big view of product and release. Every team member participate the planning and make the decision and commitment by themselves. This part overrun 1.5 hours as many detailed plan/risk are touched.

Management review and problem solving is held in the evening after whole day planning. Each ART share the 1st day’s output including feature backlog, plan, dependencies/risk, challenging etc. It has a long discussion regarding the release alignment, feature commitment, team capacity and customer needs.
The first day is a long day meeting and it’s amazing to have all people to align the schedule and plan all tasks together.

On the 2nd day, PI planning started with quick update for the 1st day planning and output of management review and problem solving meeting.
Every team continued their breakdown based on the input from RTE, PM and dependent team. Team more focused on risk, dependency and problem solving in 1 and half hour.
The final plan is worked out after lunch and every team present the final plan. RTE checked every risk/dependency from team and categorized them into “Owner, Accepted, Resolved and Mitigated). Most risks are resolved in the review meeting. Every open risk is assigned with specific owner to follow up after meeting.

Final confidence vote is given after all team’s final plan review. This is the most excited moment. Everyone is checked and all vote is >=3. Picture and video is taken to demo our confidence.

The last but not least, planning retrospective is held. There is separate board prepared to post “what we did well” and “what we need to improve in next PI”.
Many good comments like “good preparation for the PI planning”, “well communicated on the planning”, “good facilitation”, “good teamwork” etc.
There were also some improvement needed, like “use electronic scrum boards”, “time schedule doesn’t match because of time difference” etc.
Good thing will be kept and the improvement will be made in next PI.
PI planning is successfully completed at 6:00PM, but many team discussion are still on-going in the meeting room. Everyone is are really moved to SAFe mode and learnt a lot from the first PI planning.
It’s a new journey for everyone on the Train.
The train head out now, on-time delivery is in everyone’s hand.

cc: Li, Ellen J. (NSB - CN/Qingdao), Zhao, Grace J. (Nokia - CN/Qingdao), Xia, Jane (NSB - CN/Qingdao), Wang, Robert (NSB - CN/Qingdao), Wang, Reggie (NSB - CN/Qingdao), He, Judy (NSB - CN/Qingdao)

messages.content_excerpt:
The 1st SAFe PI Planning for UDM

On Aug 1st, the first SAFe PI planning was launched in UDM Tribe after two months preparation. UDM Kicked-off SAFe Transformation from end of May and immediately identified key roles & responsibility, started SAFe training, defined the Value stream & ART & new process & tools, create prioritized single backlog etc. And everything and everyone is ready to launch PI planning after rehearsal in week 30.

Entire Qingdao UDM team and key roles from BLR joined the PI planning in Demo center. BLR team member remotely joined video conference. After a quick open speech from SPC Jef, PI planning started with business context from business owner (Prasad Manapoty) covering the current market share (No.1 in the world), competition, customer view and expectations from the Tribe. Followed by Product/Solution Vision from product manager (Nathan Liu), this cover our product vision, PI objectives and prioritized feature backlog. System Architecture (Cs, Kiran) delivered the architecture highlight and evolution roadmap. Quality team delivered new quality metrics and quality criteria in SAFe mode.
After that, CI and NetAct adaption team shared the PI level plan and milestone for the common activities. RTE(Robert Wang) explain the whole PI planning process/tools, key check point and timeslot before lunch.

In the afternoon, 2 rounds of team break out are planned. attachments.content_excerpt:
Nokia Quality: Lean Six Sigma belt management program update (Aug 2018)

Dear all,

Since its launch in 2012, Nokia Quality’s Lean Six Sigma Belt Certification program has been an integral element to our sustained improvement efforts, delivering financial impact more than 707 mEUR and over 1000 certified belts!

As part of our continuous efforts to improve the program and further accelerate the business impact, we have now simplified the Belt Certification process and streamlined your user experience.
I am pleased to share the following key improvements effective August 15th, 2018:

• Simplified class enrolment - Blue Belt and Green Belt candidates will be able to enrol to classroom training quickly and easily. A simplified project proposal is required to be submitted to Continuous Improvement (CI) project Repository to be able to enrol for a classroom training. No further approvals will be required in addition.

• Simplified Blue Belt & Green Belt certification path in the Learning and Development Hub (LDH) with fewer steps.

• Reduced number of approvals – 30% reduction in the required approvals for Blue Belt/Green Belt certification path. Refer to Nokia Quality Certifications Procedure and updated Blue Belt & Green Belt Project Storyboard Template for details.

• Improved Continuous Improvement Community of Practice (CI CoP) to address key needs for different user groups: candidates, certified belts, mentors and champions.

• Simplified Nokia Quality Certifications Procedure in slide format to easily review nomination and certification requirements for different CI certifications (Orange, Purple, L6S Belt certifications). The previous Lean Six Sigma Certification procedure is now converted to a Work Instruction document for further reference.

I do believe that you will find these changes helpful, and I welcome your feedback to enhance further as needed.

Best regards,
Ashutosh Pandey
Head of Strategic Quality Transformation (SQT)
#livingquality

P.S : After the go-live today, minor changes on the associated tools (CI CoP, QIPP) will continue to be updated till the end of August 2018.
----------
Useful Links:
1. Class enrollment project proposal : https://nokia.sharepoint.com/sites/cicop/CICOPDocuments/030_Templates/10_Projects_Proposal_Template/
2. CI project repository: https://nokia.sharepoint.com/sites/PR-Q22018/
3. Nokia Quality Certifications Procedure: https://nokia.sharepoint.com/sites/cicop/SitePages/Nokia-Quality-Certifications-Procedure.aspx
4. CI Community of Practice: https://nokia.sharepoint.com/sites/cicop/SitePages/Home.aspx
5. Project Storyboard Templates: https://nokia.sharepoint.com/sites/cicop/SitePages/Projects-Templates-(Storyboard).aspx

cc: Arora, Deepti (Nokia - US/Naperville), Cox, Ian (Nokia - GB/Bristol), Sherwood, Rob (Nokia - US/Naperville), Hebert, Monique (Nokia - US/Naperville), Schroepfer, Scott (Nokia - US/Naperville), Nicosia, John (Nokia - US/Murray Hill), Lhospital, Jj (Nokia - US/Naperville), Tam, Jim (Nokia - CA/Ottawa), Roznovsky, John (Nokia - US/Naperville), Messer, Tilo (Nokia - DE/Munich), Hoover, Clinton (Nokia - US/Irving), Nanda, Vic (Nokia - US/Irving), Samuel Pon, Rajesh (Nokia - SG/Singapore), Karlova, Arina (Nokia - EE/Tallinn)

body.parsed:
Nokia Qingdao was invited to Future Intelligent Business Summit 

On Aug.15, Nokia Qingdao was invited to attend Future Intelligent Business Summit hosted by Qingdao government and Tuya Smart, which aimed to help traditional enterprises adapt to new intelligent changes, reshape and magnify their own value in new business model with smart commerce.

In the summit, several influential guests were invited to present and share the new-edged smart industry and market potentials in China. Mr. Qiu baoxing, director of Chinese Academy of Sciences, shared “Smart city reconstruction potentials in China”, which enlightened us the current status of smart city construction and our future & potentials of smart energy, air condition, internet, transportation and water services, etc.

Then the CEO of Tuya Smart shared their IoT platform and their smart products. They have integrated the upstream, like Ali Cloud service and downstream industry chain as to provide smart services to traditional companies just like Walmart, Costco, Changhong, TCL, etc.

Haier smart home appliances also shared their Cosmoplat – Haier’s large-scale customization platform which supports Haier’s smart home compliances.

In the end, Haier introduced their entrepreneurial platform “海创会“ which aims to provide incubation platform for startups with Haier industry resources as well as open social resources.

All in all, it’s a fruitful summit with many industry elites attracted. There would be huge market potentials in smart industry in recent years. So it’s also a good opportunity for us to learn and get to know the real cases and products close to life and think about our future potentials in related industry.

body.parsed:
MN QD "Leading SAFe" Training

On Aug-16 & Aug-17, MN QD continues the roll out of "Leading SAFe" trainings. 42 trainees from TAS, MSS&MGW and Het-RAN tribes joined the training. People had a good discussion on SAFe principles, Lean-Agile mindset and configuration of SAFe, etc. All participants also enjoined the simulation of PI planning. 

With the SAFe knowledge from the training, each team had a wonderful presentation as a ending of the training to show their analysis and action plan for SAFe implementation in the future. Lets' looking forwarding to their good achievement by SAFe.

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story - 8

Tina Hinch (Tribe Leader, MN CC TAS R&D)

Each stage of my career allowed me to attain new learning and apply new skills:

Jumping in with both feet – Bright-eyed and out of college, I joined Bell Labs on a new data switching project consisting of about 50 people, requiring all of us to play multiple roles simultaneously - specification, development, testing and customer support. This laid an important foundation for my career and cemented my belief that you should not set boundaries, and you don’t need a title to lead.
Leading by example – I became a technical manager of a group of digital switching SW developers.  Learned that, to achieve results through others, one needs to communicate a clear vision, motivate, lead by example and be willing to go to bat for one’s team.
Horizontal growth – I took on a group whose mission was to explore new SW development concepts. Learned to dream big, try and fail (and get back on one’s feet) fast.  
Earning customers trust : I became director of several exclusive projects for AT&T.  Honed my skill in building a trusted partnership with customers. The relationship built during this time proved to have sustained benefits for years to come.
Team unification: The merging of Alcatel and Lucent landed me a job as R&D and solution leader for the IMS portfolio.  Instilled one-team spirit from collection of teams with diverse heritage and modes of working by setting single focus on customer.  

Now as tribe leader of TAS R&D, I find myself leveraging all the above tools accumulated over the course of my career to help NTAS get back on track on quality and schedule. 

Never stop learning. Don’t limit yourself. Lead by taking initiatives to win customers and achieve great business results. Have the courage to do the right thing. 

5 C’s of leadership: Competence, Courage, Communication, Constancy (of Purpose), (Moral) Compass.

**********************************************************************
 If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer!

MN Cloud Core Career Story - 8

Tina Hinch (Tribe Leader, MN CC TAS R&D)

Each stage of my career allowed me to attain new learning and apply new skills:

Jumping in with both feet – Bright-eyed and out of college, I joined Bell Labs on a new data switching project consisting of about 50 people, requiring all of us to play multiple roles simultaneously - specification, development, testing and customer support. This laid an important foundation for my career and cemented my belief that you should not set boundaries, and you don’t need a title to lead.
Leading by example – I became a technical manager of a group of digital switching SW developers. Learned that, to achieve results through others, one needs to communicate a clear vision, motivate, lead by example and be willing to go to bat for one’s team.
Horizontal growth – I took on a group whose mission was to explore new SW development concepts. Learned to dream big, try and fail (and get back on one’s feet) fast.
Earning customers trust : I became director of several exclusive projects for AT&T. Honed my skill in building a trusted partnership with customers. The relationship built during this time proved to have sustained benefits for years to come.
Team unification: The merging of Alcatel and Lucent landed me a job as R&D and solution leader for the IMS portfolio. Instilled one-team spirit from collection of teams with diverse heritage and modes of working by setting single focus on customer.

Now as tribe leader of TAS R&D, I find myself leveraging all the above tools accumulated over the course of my career to help NTAS get back on track on quality and schedule.

Never stop learning. Don’t limit yourself. Lead by taking initiatives to win customers and achieve great business results. Have the courage to do the right thing.

5 C’s of leadership: Competence, Courage, Communication, Constancy (of Purpose), (Moral) Compass.

**********************************************************************
If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer!

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story - 7

Marcelo Cheminn Madruga (Tribe Leader, MN CC Core Productization)

I joined the former Siemens  COM in 2002 as Trainee in the hardware/embedded S/W team, and then Nokia and Siemens merged, and then finally it became only Nokia. 

During my 16 years in the “same company” I had pleasure to work in different projects, technologies and people. I start as engineer working with FPGA and x86 assembly, and later  play different roles in various R&D teams covering all areas, HW, SW, Testing, Architecture, Project Management. Also I had the pleasure to live 5 countries and learn different cultures. 

I am very proud to say that I contributed to build products from scratch and bring them successfully to the market. Being a small form factor access gateway, an ATCA Media Gateway, a Testing Protocol Simulator, a new interface card or a cloud native application, always there are ups and downs, but the learnings and the journey are always rewarding.  

What drives me is my engineer heart, that strong will to build and get something solved and done together as team. Challenges, Team Work, Fun and Working Hard is all part of a good and prosperous work environment. As leaders we need to strive to build such environment so we can make Nokia and each of us successful. 

**********************************************************************
 If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer!

Coffee & Connect Program

We would like to launch Qingdao TC Coffee & Connect program. It is open and safe talk. We may discuss the general or specific items eg culture, diversity, quality, career development, policy, process, training or whatever topics you are concerned. We hope it enables us to identify problems and gaps, and take accurate actions to address them. 

Time : The Forth Friday afternoon 
Approach: Just send email to TC-office (technologycenter.qingdao@nokia-sbell.com) 1 day before to reserve the timeslots
Room:  TC Office in the 2nd east area

QD TC-Office

attachments.content_excerpt:
I'd like to share a summary of the Customer Engagement Survey (CES) feedback. Starting with the overall Nokia CES - the 12mmw CPV is 56.9% (as of Aug 13th) which compares to Huawei at 62.0% and Ericsson at 53.0%. There is no MN score available, but since MN accounts for most of the Nokia business, the Nokia score is highly aligned to the MN performance. Since high CPV scores are correlated with higher revenues and market share - it is in the best interests of each one of us to take action to improve the Nokia CPV score.

Looking to the customer feedback specific to MN, the attribute with the largest number of comments is Design Quality at 1310 comments in the last 12 months, of which 60.6% are positive. We should be quite proud of this feedback. We must also recognize this performance is not good enough because we receive strong feedback from our leading customers that our current quality performance is insufficient. So let's celebrate the high positivity status and use this as motivation to build even higher quality hardware, software, documentation and solutions.

The second and third most commented attributes are Roadmap Execution (25.6% positive) and Feature Content (46.3% positive). You read that right - both attributes are well below 50% positivity. This feedback also appears as competitive pressures when our leaders talk with customers F2F. Internally, we see the result of these poor scores - manifested as pressure to inject additional features into programs after P2 and I6.

How can we improve our performance in these two attributes, and reduce the late injection of features into programs? Throughout MN, we each play a role in improving our performance. Improvement opportunities exists in feature candidate injection into the feature screening process, reduced prioritization of features never activated, faster and higher quality R&D and Test performance, as well as improved installability. Everyone can take a role in improving our performance.

In MN, we have a CPV champions network - colleagues representing each part of MN, who are leading the analysis and actioning of our current CPV gaps. This network of leaders is led by Delorenzo, Bob (Nokia - US/Irving) - please reach out to him to learn more, to find the colleague representing your unit, and to help improve our results.

cc: Arora, Deepti (Nokia - US/Naperville), Mathew, Siby (Nokia - IN/Bangalore), Rouanne, Marc (Nokia - FR/Paris-Saclay)

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story - 6

Julia Szatmari (Tribe Leader, MN CC MSS/MGW R&D)

I’ve started to work for Nokia in 2000 as a fresh graduate (well, actually still in my last year of university studies) as a SW development engineer. I have never wanted to be a SW developer, still I got caught by Nokia from the first day  – by its culture, the people, the mission and yes, the work itself as well. 
I’ve been working in many different roles covering the whole product development lifecycle, R&D team leader, program management, customer support, business improvement, and R&D head currently. 
I am passionate about product development, R&D and I like very much working with people. I am proud of what we have achieved with my teams, going through many challenging situations, being able to transform (organization, way of working, mindset, …) to adopt to changing environment. I like changes, I like learning new things, I like being pushed out of comfort zone. I love seeing people developing, reaching their own career goals, succeeding in the job they do. And providing high quality solution for any kind of issue (let it be new feature, an interesting SW fault or a difficult leadership topic) always makes me happy and satisfied.

My recommendations for career development:
Give your maximum in the job, whatever it is. But find the time to relax. Be reliable, so that your colleagues can be sure you do what you promise and you do it well. There is some kind of „yes” to every question. Stay positive! You need „friends”, sponsors, who remember you when the time comes, be visible. Be independent and protect your authority. But ask for help when you need it. Don’t give up, you cannot always succeed. You do not have to be ready for „next step” but you have to be convincing about your potential. Own your career and develop yourself. For girls: be brave, Nokia values the gender diversity. 
But most important: Find your passion and love what you do!

**********************************************************************
If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer!

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story - 5

Dimitris Papadimitriou (Tribe Leader, MN CC SDL R&D)

I joined the company in 1997 as a SW developer. Working in a cutting-edge technology industry and being member of a fast-growing team, I had the chance to work for several projects and test my skills in a number of different R&D roles. The frequent changes, especially in the first years of my career, helped me understand and develop my strengths and work through my weak points. In 2006, I started making my first steps in a leadership role and soon I managed to get extensive experience with high growth, fast-evolving products as well as non-target portfolio products. Since then, I worked-with and led large (500+), multi-site organizations with multi-cultural global teams in US, Germany, Finland, India, China. I have worked for products like EWSD / hiE, hiQ (softswitch and application server), AGCF, Flexi NG (EPC), MME (EPC) and SDL (SDM), covering mostly core network area. Currently, I’m tribe lead for SDL R&D and work-with teams in the UK, India, France and Greece.
I find really exciting to work in an industry that changes radically almost every 10 years. Managing the frequent changes is challenging, but also makes the work extremely interesting.
I really love working in a global environment. I enjoy meeting and working with people from different cultures.
I always like to explore alternative solutions to problems and have an open-mind about what will work best. I enjoy troubleshooting issues, understanding the details and coming up with solutions in a timely manner.
I'm highly organized, focused on my work priorities and able to multi-task. This helps me to be productive and efficient.
I try to be always on top of my projects, but I do welcome input and will consult with team members to ensure we're all on the same track.
Career is a journey with several horizontal and a few vertical moves. What matters most is that at each step, role or task someone gets knowledge and adds value.

**********************************************************************
If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer!

The frequent changes, especially in the first years of my career, helped me understand and develop my strengths and work through my weak points. In 2006, I started making my first steps in a leadership role and soon I managed to get extensive experience with high growth, fast-evolving products as well as non-target portfolio products. Since then, I worked-with and led large (500+), multi-site organizations with multi-cultural global teams in US, Germany, Finland, India, China. I have worked for products like EWSD / hiE, hiQ (softswitch and application server), AGCF, Flexi NG (EPC), MME (EPC) and SDL (SDM), covering mostly core network area. Currently, I’m tribe lead for SDL R&D and work-with teams in the UK, India, France and Greece.
I find really exciting to work in an industry that changes radically almost every 10 years. Managing the frequent changes is challenging, but also makes the work extremely interesting.
I really love working in a global environment. I enjoy meeting and working with people from different cultures.
I always like to explore alternative solutions to problems and have an open-mind about what will work best. I enjoy troubleshooting issues, understanding the details and coming up with solutions in a timely manner.
I'm highly organized, focused on my work priorities and able to multi-task. This helps me to be productive and efficient.
I try to be always on top of my projects, but I do welcome input and will consult with team members to ensure we're all on the same track.
Career is a journey with several horizontal and a few vertical moves. What matters most is that at each step, role or task someone gets knowledge and adds value.

**********************************************************************
If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer!

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story - 4

Hari Kumar (Tribe Leader, MN CC One-NDS R&D)

I joined the former Siemens Communications in 1995 right out of college.  Later Siemens Com was merged with Nokia.

I started my career as a software developer and have had the good luck and fortune to play different roles in the R&D teams. I have worked in the Network Management System, Customer Experience Management and Subscriber Data Management domains. I am proud of all the achievements that we have working together as teams right from the first software module that we developed in 1995 to the last one we delivered in 2017. There have been challenges during the journey and we overcame those and learnt together.

What drives me at work are the team and the passion to help solve problems for our customers and deliver high quality solutions. Continuous (or relentless) learning pushes me to the next level. I believe that learning combined with boundary-less collaboration within the organization will help Nokia  win in the market.  When we help Nokia win, we grow.

**********************************************************************
If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer!

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story - 3

Grace Zhao (Tribe Leader, MN CC UDM R&D)

I joined Lucent in 1998 right out of college, as a software developer and architect. I like build system architecture and debug problems. In the first 8 years of my career, I focused on the technical growth, and built a strong base for telecommunication & software development in different types of products.

Because of product crisis in AT&T Cingular, I was nominated as the customer support manager in 2006, who needs to turn around the emergency situation very quickly. After one and half years hard working, we finally got the system stabilized and customer gave us high recognition for the best product in Cingular network. I learnt a lot from this experience for what customer is really caring about, how to handle crisis with high pressure and how the product should be designed to be the best product.

In 2009, I started leading IMS solution Product Management and end to end solution testing in China.  It was a tough but joyful journey in promoting IMS solution. With team, we did quite amount of innovations and go-to-market activity to build the competitiveness of the whole solution. I got much deeper understanding on the whole chain of product from development to market, and most importantly what innovation means to a team and to a product.

Besides experiencing different roles, I led different R&Ds including core network products, Network Management product, SBC,  Fix Access Network integration and solution releases. Starting from 2014, I was pulled in to lead 8650 SDM across global teams to stabilize the quality, then till today. I feel lucky to meet so many talent people and great leaders in company, and I am willing to support others’ career whenever I can help.

I’d think following factors are the important ones for my career: 
	1) Being accountable and being helpful
	2) Systematic thinking: People, Product, Customer, Technology
	3) Constant learning
	4) Innovation and Execution

**********************************************************************
If you have your own career story, you can also publish it in Yammer!

body.parsed:
【NOKIA QD WLN】关注健康，爱护身体 – “健康周”活动圆满结束
“关注健康，爱护身体”。NOKIA QD WLN举行的“健康周”活动在7月31日拉开帷幕。作为本次健康周活动的重头戏，WLN从青岛市立医院邀请了多位骨科专家大夫来到NOKIA QD研发，为大家带来了预防白领病专题讲座，讲座非常贴合我们办公室一族长期伏案的工作特点，着重介绍了颈椎、肩部、腰肌劳损、骨关节及鼠标手疾病的识别、预防及康复锻炼。讲座之余还在现场教授了办公室工间操，帮助大家在工作间隙适当进行身体相关部位的运动锻炼。针对有明显白领病症状的同事，专家们还现场提供了适当的治疗及后期锻炼指导。活动吸引了众多同事参加，有50多名同事参加了讲座，近一半的同事得到医生的指导建议，另有需要后期诊疗的同事也和医生预约领取到了免费诊疗券。活动现场气氛热烈，大家争相跟专家们咨询讨论，很多同事反馈这类活动来的太及时了，都是大家日常需要注意的内容，身体好才能更好地工作。
同时，在健康周活动中，WLN还为大家精心准备了每日一贴，每天就每项白领病进行了详细的分享，内容涵盖如何识别疾病、如何预防、如何治疗、如何运动保健，切实让每一位同事都了解并注意白领病。并且把工间操现场教学录制成视频，随每日一贴共享给所有同事，方便没有到现场参加活动的同事进行学习。

Be Healthy Together - Nokia Qingdao Health Week Activity from WLN Team

The “Health Week” activity from Nokia QD WLN team was launched on July 31, 2018. ”Be careful of our health, be careful of our bodies” is the activity slogan.
As the opening of this activity, WLN team invited the orthopedics experts from Qingdao Municipal Hospital to give the health lecture about White-collar diseases, and teach the work-break exercises. For people who have overt symptom, the doctors also provided additional real-time treatment and exercise rehabilitative guidance. This activity got well support from all and became popular among colleagues. About 50 people subscribed the real-time treatment, and the atmosphere during the activity was kept warm and high. Many people said the lecture was well designed for them who sitting in office for long time during daily work, and gained a lot from the lecture and especially from real-time treatment.
Besides the lecture and exercise teaching, WLN team also delivered below daily health newsletters in “Health Week” about White-collar diseases, help people understand serial of White-collar diseases, then know how to prevent them and how to recover from them.
Day 1: Work-break Exercise Teaching
Day 2：Prevention of Cervical Spondylosis
Day 3：Prevention of Shoulder Disease
Day 4：Prevention of Lumbar Muscle Strain
Day 5：Prevention of Osteoarthritis
Day 6：Prevention of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

cc: [[user:1639993032]], [[user:1610777031]]

body.parsed:
The Nokia way culture is to help us unlock people’s potential, execute on our strategy with maximum impact and achieve our vision. This workshop aims to instill Nokia culture by leading the Nokia Way with Courage, Responsibility and Accountability.

It was a great session with attractive “Culture Game Play”, Cody's best practice sharing, and practical “Drive-Dare-Care Case Study” followed by a hot group discussion on how to develop ourselves towards a strong leader. 

All the SGLs have committed to bring the discussion into the team and everyone can be a leader with courage, responsiblity and accountablity.  

Thanks Henry, MN China HRBP for the great support and thanks Michael for overall cooridnation and faciliate.

body.parsed:
5G Dream Factory idea collection in Qingdao

With QD Innovation Team’s broad promotion, the 5G Dream Factory Program is widely acknowledged in QD site.
Ideas were received from many teams and initially filtered, 12 brand new ideas were received, which well fit the 3 major characteristics of future 5G network (eMBB, mMTC, URLLC).
Those 12 ideas were properly packed and submitted to 5G Dream Factory board, and waiting for board review.

1, Intelligent Parking Lot – MN – Conan Gao
2, LoRa Based Intelligent Community Property Management – FN – Leo Wang
3, Real Time VR + Live Telecast – MN – Tommy Yin
4, Remote Real Time Surgery System – AA – Laky Wang
5, Smart Water Meter for Water utilization Measurement and Control – FN – Ryan
6, 3D Building Navigation – FN – Baron Wang
7, Car Accident Online Judging – MN – Winston Qiu
8, Enhanced Face Scanning System at the Railway Station – FN – Andy Wu
9, HD SCADA of ITS – FN – Gino Pei
10, Guard Against Theft Based on LoRa – FN – Michael Miao
11, AI Aided Self Sports Training – MN – Jessica Chen
12, Real Time Earthquake Alert – AA – Joyce Chen

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story - 2

Matthias Reiss (Head of Operations & Transformation, Cloud Core)

I joined Siemens in 1989 at a very exciting time, it was the rise of ATM switching. My first role was very close to standardization and tech labs developing the newest technology. Adding business interest positioned me to become product manager in wireless access systems where I pushed a cost efficient solution based on standard components (DECT), soon I product managed cordless PBX systems with a small team globally. 
My radio responsibility grew to include everything which had an antenna, i..e.2G, 3G and TD-SCDMA. The biggest achievement for my leadership team was to turn around the complex radio business with NEC as 3G partner, Huawei as TD partner and about 3,000 own engineers. In subsequent role as head of LTE Prod Management I again used my skills in partnering (Panasonic) to make first inroads into DoCoMo/Japan business. However, on this journey I had also taken up roles like head of Business Development, Program Management, and Transformation. The broad technical, management and intercultural background helped me to move into new areas , as e.g. “Core” where I was leading the SDM business line until recently. 
At work I’m driven from the business angle and I’m fascinated from our global footprint and diversity of our teams. Always on my mind is the question about what we can do to win, to improve, differentiate, and innovate based on excellent technology and competence of our team. To all of this the answer is in the teams - building on individual strength and different cultural backgrounds. I love to combine those to come to leading global solutions for Nokia. 
The most important for your career is to maintain curiosity for new things and the desire to take on new challenges. You need to leave you comfort zone to develop. To succeed in next levels it is of particular importance to win & excite teams, colleagues, and partners towards a common goal. In my experience the art of team building can be seen outside line responsibility. So, it can be experimented and trained every day ...

body.parsed:
MN Cloud Core Career Story -1

Jonathan Harvey (Head of Cloud Core DU)

I have had varied work experience prior to joining Nokia. Starting in 1985, I spent 12 years in the British Army as a Communications Engineer. I was responsible for CS and PS Core, HF, VHF and Microwave Radio and Satellite systems. I had lots of roles inc. field support, operations, systems engineering and instructing. My time in the Army was very rewarding and taught me how to flexibly move between roles and technologies, and how deal with high pressure, mission-critical situations. 
 
After the Army, I spent 5 years with NEC starting as a Project Engineer, progressing to Program Manager and then Business Development Manager for Satellite Earth Stations, Microwave, TV Broadcast and Satellite payload. This included working in Japan and Malaysia, and globally customer-facing. 3G was starting and NEC partnered with Siemens, so I pushed to be promoted to head a new 3G Mobile unit. I was also the Program Director for the Manx Telecom 3G project (Europe’s first 3G network) and technically managed the 3UK UTRAN roll-out. My time in NEC was important as I moved to take more business responsibility.
 
After 5 years with NEC, I accepted the position of CTO for Siemens COM in the UK. In this role I headed the Technical Sales and Bid Management team (and account managed O2 UK). I was also responsible for leading major Siemens managed service bids; e.g. BBC Technology and 3UK network outsourcing. After 5 years with Siemens, I was head-hunted to be CTO EMEA in a UK-based start-up called Apertio. This role was customer-facing and responsible for technical sales, solution architecture, bid and product management for a highly disruptive SW innovator driving the SDM market. After 4 years, Apertio was acquired by NSN.
 
Joining Nokia in 2008, my first role was heading Product Management for SDM – responsible for the combined Apertio, Siemens and Nokia registers portfolio. I then headed the SDM Business Line until Liquid Core Business Line was formed and I became Head of Product Management for IMS/VoLTE and SDM. I then applied to head up the Core pre-sales team in VCM (Value Capture Management). This team was disbanded, and I then had to look for another position. I took the role of Head of Cloud Core Product Sales – this role was responsible for the Core sales strategy and pre-sales globally. Finally, in Oct 2017 I was offered the opportunity to head Cloud Core DU. 
 
There are a number of common factors which I believe are responsible for my career progression:
Willingness to move – in my case this has been to different companies, positions, roles and technologies. Flexibility is key in our constantly changing industry.
Taking responsibility – I am a firm believer in taking responsibility and ownership, sometimes this can be painful but it is always a learning exercise.
Customer facing – I love engaging with customers on all aspects of what we do, from fluffy marketing pitches to depth technical discussions.
Constantly learning – I have learnt huge amounts from every job and every situation I have been in – all of that experience is then applied to the next job…
Job satisfaction – this is more of a mindset and attitude than anything else. I have always had 100% job satisfaction and I love the job I do. 
 
It is also essential to have some way of offloading and decompressing from the pressures and frustrations of work. I enjoy spending time with my family and to completely clear my head, I train and take part in marathon kayak races.

attachments.title: Curious how you can develop your Career?  Check out what MN Cloud Core has launched...
attachments.content_excerpt:
“Awareness about the career development process and opportunities in Cloud Core” was one of the key areas to improve from last Change Map survey results.

Acknowledging the importance of this feedback, MN CC Leadership team initiated a project to support personal development and career progression of MN CC employees. The Core team consisting of senior leaders from all major Cloud Core sites worked on this project. A multi-dimensional approach was taken to arrive at meaningful actions which will have a positive impact on the key concerns.

The Core Team worked on three fronts:

1.  Understand Internal feedback from employees working in different roles from the six major sites
2.  Study the career framework of Progressive Companies in the external market
3.  Study the Career Development Journey from the central Nokia team.

Considering these inputs, the project team came up with following actions:

- A Career Map to depict various ways in which you can build your career in Nokia according to your interests
- A Manager Workshop: Managers will be trained to use the Career Development framework and to develop skills in having meaningful and impactful career development discussions
- Career Stories: Live case studies of different Nokia employees who worked in Nokia for decades, contributing to its success while achieving personal goals are available to learn from
- FAQs to guide Career Development
- Guidance on Career Coaching

We are happy to rollout the MN Cloud Core Career Development actions. Tribe Leaders and Squad Group Leaders will share details in the team meetings and All Hands meetings in the coming weeks.

Nokia Career Development Journey is a structured approach to personal development with the support of the Manager and Career Coaches. For more information on the Career Development Journey and what has been done in MN Cloud Core check out

https://nokia.sharepoint.com/sites/people/focus/Career_Development/Pages/default.aspx

MN CC Career framework has enhanced this journey by providing Career Map and Career Stories.

Jonathan Harvey                                   Madhu Bisht
Head of MN Cloud Core                       HR Business Partner Cloud Core

cc: Bisht, Madhu (Nokia - IN/Bangalore)

body.parsed: MN Q2 performance and priorities.
body.plain: MN Q2 performance and priorities.(1 Share attached)
body.rich: MN Q2 performance and priorities.

attachments.title: A message from Marc Rouanne concerning our business performance in Q2 2018 and our priorities going forward
attachments.content_excerpt:
Dear Colleagues,

You will have seen from Rajeev’s update that 5G is coming, and that it is up to all of us to deliver on the promise that 5G brings for our customers, and our company. As I have said previously, my three key priorities for this year continue to be Quality, Competitiveness, and Speed. Each element is critical to our reaching our potential so I will outline further thoughts on all three. First let me share with you the financial results for this Quarter.

Financials
This Quarter MN posted net sales of EUR 1565 million. Revenue came in well above Annual Plan and also higher on a Quarter-on-Quarter (Q-o-Q) basis, and slightly higher on a Year-on-Year (Y-o-Y) basis in constant currency. Operating Profit ended at a slight loss for the Quarter but favorable versus Plan with higher Net Sales offset by lower margins and higher R&D spending. NAM and India Y-o-Y revenue outperformance was offset by Europe, APJ and China, and with small cells, core, and microwave Development Units (DU’s) all higher on a Q-o-Q and Y-o-Y basis. Order Intake and a good book-to-bill ratio were both positive in the Quarter. As we continue to invest in R&D to meet 5G commitments this is good news, yet we have to continue to maintain discipline as Q2 also bought declines on a Y-o-Y basis for gross margin, and sales margin.

Quality
Last week the MN Leadership Team spent time discussing several code reds that have materialized. One of the sources of these challenges is E2E collaboration which has to become faster through better collaboration between teams. With better visibility and tooling like SAFe JIRA-backlog and central Continuous Integration (CI)-tracking, people can understand what is blocking progress when, and how this can affect the big picture. Using tools like O365, including MS Teams, creates better levels of intensity with faster collaboration instead of unnecessary emails, meetings and lengthy planning. Delays can’t come as a surprise. We should be able to predict and fix before the delay materializes. This requires an ‘E2E left-shift’ mindset within MN (analyzing – and fixing - what is causing the fire and not just the fire itself).

Our performance during the first 6 months shows us that we are not yet on the right trajectory to meet – and beat – our MN Quality scorecard targets. Reference Architecture Compliance levels at P2 and P8 are above target and Critical Customer Issues Solution Timeliness is improving, yet currently missing its target. Confirmed outages, whilst improving slightly, are also still not meeting target levels. We are committed to results and transparency in MN and we are focused on those DU’s that are underperforming. This means deep dives for each DU focusing on Product, Release and Customer cause profiles, and recovery action plans developed at Unit Dedicated Quality Review and reviewed at Unit Ops Review-level.

With the left-shift initiative score now in place, we have an assessment of the health of our Development Units left-shift programs and, more importantly, are identifying where greater focus is needed. Several DU’s have shown good results including HetRAN, who achieved a ~60% reduction of customer fault arrival compared to 1H2017 results. In other DU’s, the left shift programs are maturing. For those DU’s who are not meeting their targets this is an issue of ownership - additional actions and resources from DU’s are required to improve the health of the left shift program. Certain lagging indicators like New Customer Defect Reports show that our customers are not yet seeing the positive results from our left shift actions

Competitiveness
You are our competitive advantage and we don't do a good job of recognizing those of you that quietly succeed. A good attitude and good results are gender neutral, and although the proportion of women in N-3 leadership roles is now at 16.5% (vs. 13.5% at the beginning of last year) there are not enough female leaders in MN. It is our ambition to fix this. The intent is 20% of MN leaders by 2020 to be female and we will be monitoring this closely. More information on #20/2020 will be announced this Quarter.

In terms of customer wins, Tommi Uitto has outlined (https://www.yammer.com/nokia.com/#/Threads/show?threadId=1112559786) the fairly strong deal momentum that has been achieved so far this year. We have approximately the same pace in deal momentum in “market share defining moments” as at this point in 2016 and 2017. Separately we have also seen very successful 5G demos at Verizon’s headquarters, and at the T-Mobile lab in the US. Our SRAN roll-out momentum continues with 201k BTS deployed (including over 11k AirScale System Modules). In LTE, a benchmarking exercise (https://www.yammer.com/nokia.com/#/Threads/show?threadId=1095453863) based on public data from 21 countries and nearly 100 cities shows that we are number 1 in the US market with 40 cities, and number 3 in the Rest of the World with 60 cities. The KPI’s used were LTE Down Link and Up Link throughput, latency and availability. We are taking key actions to enhance our competitiveness with a roadmap acceleration program focusing on 5G, LTE and SRAN with all key features being measured against the best of the competition; a TCO war room for all configurations including massive MIMO cost competitiveness improvements; a Serviceability acceleration across the radio and core portfolio jointly with Global Services; and Product Security enhancements.

Meanwhile, in China, a crucial market for us, we can see great teamwork, and a great outcome. Last month’s 5G trial Phase III result (https://www.yammer.com/nokia.com/#/Threads/show?threadId=1110483564) announced by MIIT at the IMT-2020 5G Summit in Shenzhen, showed solid progress, and a number of achievements, including Nokia being the only vendor to complete a 4.9G RRU test, and we were the first vendor to complete a 5G NR call through a third party terminal based on a real core network on NSA infrastructure. More recently, we have the good news of the China Mobile frame agreement (https://www.nokia.com/en_int/news/releases/2018/07/10/nokia-and-china-mobile-sign-eur-1-billion-frame-agreement) to celebrate.

Speed
Working closer with customers can improve time to market with a direct effect on customer outcomes, giving us more opportunities to celebrate. We therefore want all tribe leaders to have direct customer interactions - this includes preparing for, attending and following up from customer meetings. We are therefore organizing training on how to work with customers for DU’s and ATF, and O365 training to make it easier for us work efficiently and collaborate better. I am also happy to see the progress being made with Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe) (https://www.yammer.com/nokia.com/#/Threads/show?threadId=1093521199) in MN. We chose SAFe to increase our collaboration and clockspeed – critical elements of our move to a faster, agile and DevOps mode of operation. It is up to all of us to take the time to understand what SAFe means for MN, and to take the necessary training where required (https://www.yammer.com/nokia.com/#/Threads/show?threadId=1108167395).

This brings me to the launch of our new NAM Unit, which is moving fast. As I said at the launch, our goal is an agile, responsive Mobile Networks Business Group that quickly adjusts to customer and market requirements. This is achieved through direct collaboration between customers and respective MN DU’s leading to a faster time to market for innovative solutions. North America (NAM) is the testbed for this goal and I am excited to see their progress so far.

Finally, I want to thank all of you who are quietly succeeding and delivering on our ambitions and reaching our targets. We can take inspiration from your execution mindsets – it is crucial that all tribe leads working with customers are empowered to make fast decisions and collaborate using new tools. When we execute well we can build on some of the many firsts achieved over the past Quarter: First Over the Air (OTA) NSA video streaming call with the Airphone at the end of April, first full L1 release for ABIL (based on 3GPP shadow specification V4) created in early May, live 5G installations in Oulu for 3.5 GHz and 28 GHz, and industry firsts, like the Edge Cloud data center solution for the 5G era. After the hard work of H1, we are now in the summer period which means many colleagues will be taking vacations during this time. I hope that everyone is able to enjoy themselves, to take some time to catch up with family and friends, and reflect on the achievements won so far, and the opportunity that lies ahead – what an exciting time to be working in MN!

With my thanks and best wishes,
Marc

cc: Rouanne, Marc (Nokia - FR/Paris-Saclay)

attachments.content_excerpt:
We often heard that cloudification & containerization are the key enablers of DevOps, that’s usually talked from the product solution point of view, but do you know it’s also a sharp weapon for the pipeline creation. 2nd Aug, we invite 5G C-Plane expert Shen Bo A to share their practice of containerized Compile & Build.

The sharing will cover below topics:
- Docker Basic
- gNB build project challenges
- Introduce Docker in gNB compile & build
- Solution evolution

Check out enclosed invitations share with your colleagues, let's meet at next Thursday.

cc: Zuo, Shuli (NSB - CN/Shanghai), Shen, Bo A. (NSB - CN/Shanghai)

attachments.content_excerpt:
In DevOps practice, how to effectively secure the product quality is always the on the hot topic list. 24th Jul, we invited 4G RAN Feature Pz Squad Group Lead Huang Weijie to share their left shift practices of strengthening quality assurance, helping fast feedback and covering NFRs in early phases, Weijie will tell us below stories:

- How to achieve weekly CRT and monthly MRT?
- Can we add capacity testing in early phase?
- Close cooperation with vendors when testing UE dependent features
- Participate SKT DevOps team and work together with customers

Check out the attached invitation and share with your teammates, looking forward to meet you in the session.

cc: Huang, Weijie (NSB - CN/Shanghai), Guan, Li Ping (NSB - CN/Beijing), Yu, Gang Gang (NSB - CN/Shanghai)

body.parsed:
NSB 5G梦工厂正式开业，现在全公司范围内收集最新，最酷，最实用的创意！
本次活动由麦叔亲自挂帅，集齐公司各团队之龙珠（人力），准备了将创新进行到底之粮草（资金），用以打造改变世界之产品。

创意要求：
1，	紧扣5G网络3大特性： 移动带宽增强（eMBB），大规模物联网（mMTC），超高可靠性超低延迟（URLLC）
2，	优秀的解决方案，以及充分的市场和社会需求

创意方案请使用附件中的模板（仅一页PPT）

投递方式（请联系各部门接口人，他们会帮助你打磨并完善你的创意）：
MN – Park Yang (park.yang@nokia-sbell.com)
A&A – Laurence Wang (laurence.wang@nokia-sbell.com)
FN – Michael Miao (michael.1.miao@nokia-sbell.com)
Overall – Matrix Wang (matrix.wang@nokia-sbell.com)

投递截止日期： 2018/7/20

Best Regards,
QD Innovation Team

本次活动由麦叔亲自挂帅，集齐公司各团队之龙珠（人力），准备了将创新进行到底之粮草（资金），用以打造改变世界之产品。

创意要求：
1， 紧扣5G网络3大特性： 移动带宽增强（eMBB），大规模物联网（mMTC），超高可靠性超低延迟（URLLC）
2， 优秀的解决方案，以及充分的市场和社会需求

创意方案请使用附件中的模板（仅一页PPT）

投递方式（请联系各部门接口人，他们会帮助你打磨并完善你的创意）：
MN – Park Yang (park.yang@nokia-sbell.com)
A&A – Laurence Wang (laurence.wang@nokia-sbell.com)
FN – Michael Miao (michael.1.miao@nokia-sbell.com)
Overall – Matrix Wang (matrix.wang@nokia-sbell.com)

投递截止日期： 2018/7/20

Best Regards,
QD Innovation Team

body.rich: Congratulations to MGC-8 team!

attachments.content_excerpt:
5060 MGC-8 Team was awarded the “Workers Pioneer” !!

Recently, the general trade union of Laoshan District, Qingdao awarded 5060 MGC-8 team the "Workers Pioneer” to commend our team's good service for RJIL over the past year.
In 2017, RJIL's complex application scenario and the unstable network environment gave us a great challenge. Our team quickly and accurately solved all of the issues site reported and optimized the MGC-8 architecture to make it more efficient for huge traffic load. RJIL was particularly satisfied with our service and granted the new contract.

body.parsed:
喊麦时刻第五期7-10

      “因为有梦想，所以我存在。我们是最好的团队！”
       这次上海展完美诠释了：“因为有梦想，所以我存在。我们是最好的团队！”，这是最好的团队协作大案例。
       今年参观客户数创历史新高，高达2800人，75%YoY增长率。CSP政企和GEPS也直线上升，到访客户996人，占总人数36%。五大展区48个技术展示，聚焦5G+ 丰富垂直行业应用案例，场景式、体验式“小小世界”展示，凸显技术价值优势。16个重磅级合作MoU和大单签署！朋友圈合作的宽度与深度得以极大提升，媒体影响力位居第二。
      诺基亚贝尔以“新央企”崭新形象亮相，牢固树立了中国市场第一阵营厂商的形象和地位。
国资委国务院采访团莅临展会，彰显央企风范。感谢上海展每位员工的努力和付出！你们用行动证明赢得客户尊重，展现诺基亚贝尔人的风采和实力！
       期待CT联手BG，务实进取，将2800位客户参观转变为实际的销售机会和订单，麦叔会优先去这些省份拜访客户喔，MCA下半年路演计划也会优先考虑这些有潜力和战斗力的省份。
      本期麦叔语录是莫言的新作《同学赞》想知道内容？大家去听麦叔的音频咯~~

body.parsed:
2018 1H Future X Award 

Last Friday (Jul-06th ), MN QD TC hold the 2018 IH Future X Award sharing and competition meeting successfully. All tribes of MN QD contributed submissions. Differentiating with the previous sessions, we invited all teams and assessors join the face to face discussion in the HR training rooms. Besides the wonderful sharing from teams, assessors and participants provided valuable comments and ideas for improvement and enhancement and expressed interest to reuse some submissions in their products. It is great to see the platform of Future X Award can benefit more than expected and congratulate NTAS China dedicated R&D team and MN CC 3G Core MGC-8 Development Scrum Teams got the winners.

attachments.content_excerpt:
As one of our star DevOps pilot project, OneLab has achieved a lot in past months even now the team suspend phase II activities, they improved the SW deployment time (from ready for release to deployment done) from 2.5 hours to couple of mins and every SW changes could be deployed to productization environment quickly if it needs. They have experienced a lot of challenges during the journey, one of the typical issue is the reliability of infrastructure (e.g EE Cloud), how did they overcome it?

We’re honored to invite Yan Meng, the CDS tools admin and Linux expert, to share the high availability solution of OneLab deployment from below aspects:

- What’s HA? The history, benefit and etc.
- HA & DevOps
- HA solution details
- Next steps

Check out the invitation and shared with your colleagues to join the session :)

cc: Yan, Meng A. (NSB - CN/Shanghai), Yan, Lei (NSB - CN/Shanghai), Fang, Zhi (NSB - CN/Hangzhou)

body.parsed:
Leading SaFe Trianing @ Qingdao TC

On Jun-21th &22th, we delivered 1st "Leading SAFe" training for Register tribes in QD. 24 trainees joined the training. This 2 days training includes SAFe core values, Lean-Agile Mindset, Principles, PI planning and several interaction activities which help trainee to understand the SAFe  People also had a good discussion with the trainer about the question of implementation and execution of ART.  Thanks Ale Zhong and DongQing Jiang’s great effort on this wonderful training as trainers.

body.parsed:
Wow! Another Lego4DevOps game was successfully held in KuTao of Qingdao site. 6 Dev guys, as well as 2 support guys participated this activity. Two teams were organized after a short introduction. The two teams went through from the "silo" mode to "common objective" mode. Their KPI were growing higher and higher with increasing communication & collaboration. In the last iteration, they delivered an excellent product to customer. This is just the DevOps culture emphasizes: communication, collaboration and common goals.
During the game, heated discussions took place even including some pain points of our corporation. For example, the barriers between Dev, Ops and customers. What a meaningful activity. Thanks all the participants, Li Zhenming, Li Weikang, Wang Joyce, Tang Tina, Zhou Candy, Li Irone, Xu Billy, Chen Marvin and processus Summer Zhang.
If you are interested in this game, join it by sending an email to Aaron Liu (aaron.a.liu@nokia-sbell.com) or Summer Zhang (yaxing.zhang@nokia-sbell.com).  The game does not require any knowledge of DevOps nor is any specific role demanded. Also, the players do not need to be from the same team. And you are welcome whether in NewCenter or KuTao.

During the game, heated discussions took place even including some pain points of our corporation. For example, the barriers between Dev, Ops and customers. What a meaningful activity. Thanks all the participants, Li Zhenming, Li Weikang, Wang Joyce, Tang Tina, Zhou Candy, Li Irone, Xu Billy, Chen Marvin and processus Summer Zhang.
If you are interested in this game, join it by sending an email to Aaron Liu (aaron.a.liu@nokia-sbell.com) or Summer Zhang (yaxing.zhang@nokia-sbell.com). The game does not require any knowledge of DevOps nor is any specific role demanded. Also, the players do not need to be from the same team. And you are welcome whether in NewCenter or KuTao.

(NSB - CN/Qingdao)

body.parsed: Excellent news -- 5G commercial contract with T-Mobile USA. This is a major milestone for all of us at Nokia. The scope is massive for Nokia MN CC.
body.plain: Excellent news -- 5G commercial contract with T-Mobile USA. This is a major milestone for all of us at Nokia. The scope is massive for Nokia MN CC.(1 Share attached)
body.rich: Excellent news -- 5G commercial contract with T-Mobile USA. This is a major milestone for all of us at Nokia. The scope is massive for Nokia MN CC.

attachments.content_excerpt:
Leading the way with T-Mobile 5GC
---
It has been an exciting week, we have now signed our 5G commercial contract with T-Mobile USA! This is a major milestone for all of us at Nokia, a deal we have been working on for the last 12 months. The scope is massive for Nokia MN CC. At the center of the deal is the T-Mobile US Universal Subscriber Database (USD) system, it compromises of One-NDS, HLR, HSS, EIR and some 20+ custom applications from GS SI all deployed on bare metal HP hardware. We will modernize USD, evolve it to Cloud and support 5G NSA and SA architectures.

We will start with HSS 18.5 upgrades to support 5G NSA with Option 3X. Next, we will modernize the solution to a Cloud based eco-system with Airframe OR 18, NADCM, Cloudband portfolio (CBIS, CBAM and CBND). All applications will migrate to Cloud based VNF's and includes our entire MN CC SDM portfolio. It will be anchored on One-NDS and later evolve to SDL. SDL 19 will initially be used for LIVE friendly user trials and evolve to SDL 19 SP1 for replacing the current One-NDS over time.

We will also deploy our 5GC portfolio on the new USD Cloud infrastructure. 5GC SA (Option 2) lab trials will begin in Jan 2019 with UDR, UDM, and AUSF and SMSF. Other 5G core solutions included in the deal are AMF, NSSF and NRF and PCF from our ION & NSW portfolio. In 2H19, we will start commercial field trials with Release 19.5 portfolio for standalone 5G system, and start migrating subscribers from One-NDS to SDL 19 SP1 baseline.

We must urgently deliver the 29 racks of Airframe OR 18 HW in the next 6-8 weeks. 4 nodes go into the new T-Mobile labs so we can certify our Cloud Infrastructure with CBIS 18. Cloud HSS 18.5 goes next, followed by other applications. While the lab verification is taking place, we need install the OR 18 HW in legacy MSO's where space, power and cooling remain key challenges for our customer. Each MSO has 8 racks with 4 racks per PoD (each POD is managed by a single CBIS instance). We need to get the NADCM and NetAct integration complete for our hardware management solution by mid-August.

We need to in parallel verify internally in the BL our E2E Cloud solutions with OR18, CBIS 18 and applications like cHSS 18.5 to start with. We will start directing traffic to the Cloud FE's and prove solution stability and scale and switch off the bare metal front ends gradually as customer gets confidence in our Cloud eco-system.

SDL 19 validation in 4Q18 is vital for us to implement a limited commercial trial in 1Q19 while we get more functionality for replacing One-NDS eco-system with SDL 19.1 in mid-2019. In parallel we will have 5GC lab trials starting in Jan 2019 and moving to commercial LIVE trials in 2H19. We will also have the T-Mobile - Sprint NewCo initiatives, and migrate subs from One-NDS to Cloud.

This is our opportunity to lead the way for Nokia to be successful with 5G. As T-Mobile leads the industry in a nationwide 5G network deployment it will help shape our products and solutions and give us the competitive edge over others in this industry.

Thank you all for your continued support.

body.parsed:
Qingdao Best Practices Festival Highlights: Session 2 – Innovating with Our Ecosystem 
 ----- > Learn how the Qingdao Location Development sets the stage internally, and collaborates with their external ecosystem to innovate and generate new business:
 - Tech papers, innovation days, cross-site best practice sharing to stimulate innovation internally
 - Future ready focus areas: 5G, IoT, Machine Learning, 3GPP standards development
 - Hackathon to explore collective problem-solving around real life issues: Mobile Internet, Intelligent Manufacturing.
 Contact: Matrix Wang

 A few guidelines: 
 1) Goal for activities:
 To unleash the creativity of employees
 2) Ways to achieve the goal:
 Setup different channels to support different types of idea to the highest achievement
 3) Steps:
 Enable, Encourage, Inspire, Incubate

Qingdao Nokia Innovation Sharing Session for VC Program Introduction

There’re several Internal Venture Capital programs running inside Nokia, which are aiming at supporting our inventors to incubate their ideas to sustainable revenue generating products. On June 22, 2018, a Webex sharing session introduced those programs, showing what’s their focus and progress and even some successful cases. 

Thanks very much to the presenters and all the participants! You can click on the programs webpage to get the details for each VC program.

The recording of Webex sharing can be found in the link as below:
https://nokia.sharepoint.com/sites/QDInnovations/publish/Shared%20Documents/GIM%202018/20180622%20-%20Audio%20of%20VC%20program%20sharing
